channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: News Analysis: A Big Blast in North Korea, and Big Questions on U.S. Policy
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, in an undated photograph made public on Tuesday, looking at a missile launch site in North Korea.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: North Korea’s most powerful nuclear test yet shows that gradually escalating sanctions are not stopping it from becoming a nuclear state.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER, CHOE SANG-HUN and JANE PERLEZ
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: North Korea’s Nuclear Blasts Keep Getting Stronger
item.media:description: Researchers at the Earthquake and Volcano Monitoring Division, in Seoul, the South Korean capital, checking the seismic waves that were measured on Friday.
item.description: The tremors caused by each test have grown larger, and the North appears closer to building a nuclear device small enough to be mounted on a missile.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: North Korea Will Have the Skills to Make a Nuclear Warhead by 2020, Experts Say
item.media:description: One of the type of mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles that North Korea is now developing, shown here in a military celebration in Pyongyang, North Korea, in October 2015.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: The Pentagon warned this year that Pyongyang’s new missiles, if perfected, “would be capable of reaching much of the continental United States.”
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Decoding North Korea’s Claim of a Successful Nuclear Test
item.media:description: Screens at the Korea Meteorological Administration, in Seoul, South Korea, showing seismic waves on Friday. The detonation was equivalent to 10 kilotons of TNT, the Defense Ministry said.
item.description: Correspondents of The New York Times provide context and analysis on the statement issued by North Korea that claimed success for a nuclear test.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Hajj Prep: Search Soul, Buy Sturdy Shoes, Pay the Dentist
item.media:description: Pilgrims in Mina, a few miles from Mecca. “I cannot begin to describe the crowds,” Diaa’s brother wrote on the family WhatsApp forum. “You will often be stuck in human traffic moving only by the will of people around you, almost like a wave carrying you.”
item.description: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent, is getting ready for her first hajj, the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. And her family and colleagues have plenty of advice.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: What Muslims Do on Hajj, and Why
item.media:description: Muslim worshipers at the Grand Mosque in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, in July last year. The black cube at the center is known as the Kaaba.
item.description: Our correspondent, who is in Saudi Arabia for the annual pilgrimage, explains why Muslims, dressed in white, throw stones, kiss a large black rock and have a goat sacrificed.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: My Hajj Reading List: Preparing for Mecca
item.description: Our correspondent shares her reading list before embarking on the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Russia and the United States Reach New Agreement on Syria Conflict
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, announced the agreement on Syria in Geneva on Friday.
item.description: If successful, the agreement would reduce the violence and lead to joint military operations to target Islamic militants in Syria.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and ANNE BARNARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 5-Year Prison Term in Iran Is Reported for Thomson Reuters Charity Official
item.description: The official, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British national, was seized more than five months ago. The accusations against her were never made clear.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: War Games Show Off Russia’s Tightening Grip on Crimea
item.description: A huge show of power, including 12,000 troops, simulated an invasion and counterattack on the Crimean peninsula, which Russia annexed from Ukraine in 2014.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Turkey Uses Post-Coup Emergency Decree to Purge Mayors and Teachers
item.media:description: The Turkish police detained a woman on Friday during a protest in Diyarbakir. Over 40,000 people have been arrested or detained since the night of a failed coup.
item.description: The government said it would take over the administrations of 28 municipalities using powers granted by a state of emergency after the failed military coup on July 15.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: The Saturday Profile: From Where Ex-Taliban Minister Sits, Demand Is Growing for Afghan Peace
item.media:description: Sayed Abdul Wasi Motasim, a former Taliban minister.
item.media:credit: Robert Nickelsberg for The New York Times
item.description: Agha Jan Motasim, a back-channel negotiator who works in secret after taking 12 bullets, insists that the Taliban are thinking about talks despite recent advances.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Canada Today: A Surge in Interest, and Prices, for Toronto’s Film Scene
item.media:description: The director Antoine Fuqua and the actor Haley Bennett at the premiere of “The Magnificent Seven” at the Toronto International Film Festival on Thursday.
item.description: Our weekly roundup for Canadian readers and anyone else interested in the True North features hot tickets in Toronto and a Stompin’ Tom Connors tribute.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Hopes Dimming for a Woman to Lead the United Nations
item.media:description: Irina Bokova, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, is seeking the secretary general post.
item.description: More women than ever entered the race to be the next secretary general. But informal polls of the Security Council suggest members are leaning to men.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Women in Terror Cell Were ‘Guided’ by ISIS, Paris Prosecutor Says
item.description: The use of a cell made up entirely of young women represents a chilling turn in the Islamic State’s tactics, the prosecutor said.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Giulio Regeni, Italian Student, Was Under Investigation in Egypt Before His Death
item.media:description: A protester held a picture of Giulio Regeni outside the Egyptian Embassy in Rome in February. The body of Mr. Regeni, an Italian doctoral candidate, was discovered near Cairo on Feb. 3.
item.description: Prosecutors acknowledged for the first time on Friday that Mr. Regeni had been under investigation before he disappeared. Egypt has denied that security officials played a role in his killing.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: VW Engineer Pleads Guilty in U.S. Criminal Case Over Diesel Emissions
item.media:description: Matthias Mueller, chief executive of Volkswagen, is displayed on a camera’s viewfinder during a news conference.
item.description: The charges add to pressure on the company, which has already reached a $15 billion settlement with car owners in the United States.
item.dc:creator: HIROKO TABUCHI and JACK EWING

item.title: House Passes Bill Allowing 9/11 Lawsuits Against Saudi Arabia; White House Hints at Veto
item.description: President Obama has long opposed the measure, warning that it could expose the United States to a raft of lawsuits by people in other countries.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER

item.title: Stuck in a Cable Car High Above Mont Blanc, Waiting for Rescue
item.media:description: A passenger on Friday who was trapped overnight in cable cars above the slopes of Mont Blanc.
item.description: All 110 people left hanging 12,500 feet in the Mont Blanc massif near Chamonix, France — including 33 who were stranded until morning — were safely evacuated.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY, LILIA BLAISE and MARTIN DE BOURMONT

item.title: News Analysis: Russia, Already Reinserting Itself in Middle East, Enters Israeli-Palestinian Fray
item.media:description: From left, Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan; President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia; and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, in Moscow last year.
item.description: Moscow wants to compete with Washington for regional influence. Israel wants to thwart the French, and the Palestinians want to elevate their standing.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: What in the World: Something Old, Something New, Something Borrowed, Something Hindu
item.description: A traditional Indian wedding can last days, and rituals include the bride kicking over a pot of rice and dance competitions between Team Bride and Team Groom.
item.dc:creator: AMISHA PADNANI

item.title: What in the World: Whether Shaved by Hand or Machine, This Roman Treat Is Just as Frosty
item.description: Purveyors of grattachecca, the traditional homegrown version of a snow cone, have spirited debates about the proper way to prepare the ice.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Opinion: The Flavors That Unite Syrians
item.description: Food is what defines the people of Syria, even after years of war and displacement.
item.dc:creator: DALIA MORTADA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Editorial: Crisis in Calais
item.description: Britain and France, two of the wealthiest countries in Europe, have failed to deal humanely with more than 10,000 people stuck in a migrant tent camp.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Angela Merkel’s Loyalty Test for German Turks
item.media:description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan at a bilateral meeting within the framework of the G20 Summit in Hangzhou, China, last week.
item.media:credit: Jseco Denzel, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Should the chancellor be questioning their patriotism? Millions of Germans think so.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SAUERBREY

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Readers React: Seeing Orange: What Caught Commenters’ Eyes About a Small Syrian Boy in a Big Chair
item.media:description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo.
item.description: Our Photo Editors’ Notebook on what made the image of Omran Daqneesh stand out inspired many readers to share their thoughts.
item.dc:creator: INSIDER STAFF
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
